history.content:
All of the course content from this past semester is available at https://cs61a.org/ (specifically https://cs61a.org/fa18, though they currently link to the same website). The content doesn't change very much from semester to semester, and even with Dan Garcia teaching it (who hasn't taught it in a while, to my knowledge) this is unlikely to change, and so the best way to prepare is to do the content itself. I would recommend going through as many lectures, labs, and discussions as you can (without burning yourself out).

-----------

Having a firm grasp on Python will greatly help your learning experience. Knowing the syntactical semantics of the language will put you several weeks ahead since the first ~3-4 weeks are dedicated to learning Python. This will allow you to stay on task for the more abstract concepts that will be taught later on.

-----------

Agreed, I would say at least learn Python and go through the lectures. Learning/understanding environment diagrams ahead of time also helped me a lot when I took the course.

-----------

You won't have as much time, but before I took it my fall semester, I went through more than half of the course lectures and did all the projects except for the Scheme interpreter. So by the time I began the class, I had all the time in the world to just do past exams, which allowed me to do pretty well in the class.

Hi! 

I am taking CS61A next semester and kinda stressed out by the difficulty of the course. I was gonna prepare for the course during the winter break, and I am wondering what are the most effective ways to nail the course? Are there some other resources that would help to prep for 61A? Please, advise. 

Thanks!!
history.subject: CS 61A
